attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of the country or subnational area (administrative division).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Board on Geographic Names, 2019; Badan Pusat Statistik, 2010

attr.attrdef: Concatenation of all administrative division names separated by underscores (“_”), beginning with the country name and ending with the division name for the lowest subnational administrative order (level). The field serves as one for name sorting and ordering.
Identical subnational area identifiers in the Unicode text table and geospatial data file, enabling linkage (joining) of the table records to the geospatial data file polygons as attributes.
First-order administrative division name (ADM1), e.g., province or state.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Board on Geographic Names, 2019; Badan Pusat Statistik, 2010

attr.attrdef: Administrative level "0" (ADM0/country); administrative level "1" (ADM1); administrative level "2" (ADM2); administrative level "3" (ADM3); administrative level "4" (ADM4).
Any notes about a country or subnational division, which may include former names or alternate names or spellings.
U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC), 2019

attr.attrdef: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) code (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS), 2019

attr.attrdef: Code used by the Central Bureau of Statistics for a subnational administrative division.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Annual Five-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for 2000 to 2020 for the national and first-order administrative division levels of Indonesia were prepared by the U.S. Census Bureau for joining (linking) to shapefiles as attribute data. The estimates are consistent with the midyear national projections from the U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (IDB).
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The U.S. Census Bureau is providing annual subnational five-year age group population estimates by sex for 2000-2020 in a geographic information system (GIS) for users of the Spatial Data Repository, funded by the U.S. President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
CENSUS DATA
Age-Sex data: Penduduk Indonesia, Hasil Sensus Penduduk Tahun 2000, Seri: L2.2. Badan Pusat Statistik, 2001 (Print only, not online. Published by province); Penduduk Indonesia, Hasil Sensus Penduduk 2010, Population by Age Group and Sex. Badan Pusat Statistik. Available online at http://sp2010.bps.go.id/index.php/navigation/wilayah (select province, select regency or municipality, select "Population Distribution," select "Population by Age Group and Sex," accessed January 31, 2019). The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of non-U.S. census and survey data.
GEOSPATIAL BOUNDARIES
International boundaries coincide with the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Available online at http://geonode.state.gov (accessed 2018). Geospatial data for the first-order administrative divisions of Indonesia were downloaded from the Database of Global Administrative Areas (GADM), available online at http://www.gadm.org/download_country_v3.html, "Indonesia" (accessed January 31, 2019). The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of boundary placements.
NATIONAL ESTIMATES AND PROJECTIONS
U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. INTERNATIONAL DATA BASE, December 2018 release, available at http://www.census.gov/data-tools/demo/idb/informationGateway.php, accessed in January 2019.
NATIONAL AND SUBNATIONAL AREA NAMES AND CODES
(1) U.S. National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. NGA GEOnet Names Server (GNS), available at http://geonames.nga.mil/gns/html/, accessed in January 2019. For geographic area names from the U.S. Board on Geographic Names and the U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) codes. (2) U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard. NSG Standards Registry, available at http://nsgreg.nga.mil/genc/discovery, accessed in January 2019.

Consts.useLimit: U.S. Census Bureau population estimates: None. Acknowledgment of the Census Bureau would be appreciated in products derived from its population estimates. GADM: "The data are freely available for academic use and other non-commercial use. Redistribution, or commercial use, is not allowed without prior permission. Using the data to create maps for academic publishing is allowed." The international boundaries are derived from the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset (public domain).

dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
SUBNATIONAL DIVISIONS
Indonesia's first-order administrative divisions: 33 provinces as of the 2010 census.
SHAPEFILES
The original shapefile from Database of Global Administrative Areas (GADM) had 502 polygons and matched the 2010 census for regencies and municipalities (ADM2) after dissolving 4 water bodies into their surrounding polygons. The U.S. Census Bureau aligned the boundaries in the shapefile to the “Large Scale International Boundary Line” (LSIB) polygon file (2018) from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Then, the Census Bureau dissolved the LSIB-aligned shapefile into 33 polygons for Indonesia's first-order administrative divisions. The final shapefile contains 33 polygons, one for each of Indonesia's first-order administrative divisions (provinces) as reported by Badan Pusat Statistik in the 2010 census.
Notes: (1) A number of regencies and municipalities split off to form new areas between the 2000 and 2010 censuses, as noted in the "USCBCMNT" field, requiring interpolation and adjustment of 2000 population data by U.S. Census Bureau staff. For new areas that were fully formed from part of a single original regency or municipality, the total population of the original area was divided proportionally according to the populations of the same areas in 2010. For new areas that were formed from parts of multiple original regencies or municipalities, the total population of the new area was divided proportionally according to the land areas of the multiple original pieces in square kilometers. Census 2000 regency and municipality polygons, Master File Kabupaten 1993 - 2002, and Master File Kabupaten 2003 - 2009, available online at http://www.bps.go.id/website/fileMenu/mfkab_93_02.pdf and http://www.bps.go.id/website/fileMenu/mfkab_03_09.pdf were consulted in determining the origin ADM2 of the split regencies and municipalities. (2) According to Badan Pusat Statistik, Aceh, Papua, and Sulawesi Tengah provinces could not be properly enumerated at the time of the 2000 census, due to security concerns. Final estimated population totals for these provinces were published in Aceh Dalam Angka 2003, Papua Dalam Angka 2003, and Sulawesi Tengah Dalam Angka 2003, respectively, and are available online at http://www.bps.go.id/. (3) The population estimates and projections produced by the U.S. Census Bureau do not directly take into account the estimated 167,540 Indonesian deaths associated with the 2004 Sumatra–Andaman earthquake and resulting tsunami that primarily affected Aceh and Sumatera Utara Provinces.
FEATURE AND ATTRIBUTE DETAILS
The 2000-2020 population estimates for Indonesia's administrative divisions are provided in the following 2 tables: The Unicode tab-delimited text file (table) "Indonesia_5yr_age_sex_2000-2020_uscb_mar2019.txt," which can be joined to the shapefile via the common field "GEO_MATCH." The Excel table "Indonesia_5yr_age_sex_2000-2020_508_uscb_mar2019.xlsx," formatted for accessibility in compliance with Section 508 of the U.S. Government's Federal Rehabilitation Act.
Details on processing of the census data and calculation of 2000-2020 estimates are provided in the "Census_Metadata" tab of the Excel file and "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas" document.
For the subnational areas, the U.S. Board on Geographic Names (BGN) "approved" names from the NGA GEOnet Names Server (cited in the "Credits") were used. For any area that a BGN name was not available, the name from the national census was used. Official codes for the subnational areas from the country's national statistical office, when available, are entered in the "NSO_CODE" field in both the text and Excel tables. Information on any alternative area names or recent name or boundary changes is entered in the "USCBCMNT" field.
A partial list of the fields in the Excel and Unicode text files, including all fields identifying geographic names and codes, is provided in the Excel file's "Data_Dictionary" tab.
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
More detail on the U.S. Census Bureau subnational age and sex group estimates and maps for PEPFAR can be found in the document "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." It includes a data dictionary that is similar to that in the Excel table.
ACCESS
The U.S. Census Bureau’s products for PEPFAR can be accessed from the SPATIAL DATA REPOSITORY:
Zipped file containing geographic boundary data, tables with subnational population estimates, and instructions for linking (joining) the text file to the geographic boundary data: http://spatialdata.dhsprogram.com/home/. This web address also provides access to data and maps from the DHS (Demographic and Health Surveys) Program.
Instructions for linking (joining) the text file to the geographic boundary data can also be found in a standalone methodology document in the Spatial Data Repository.
For more information, see the following methodology documents in the Spatial Data Repository: (1) "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." (2) "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas."
All of the above documents, tables, and geographic boundary data (zipped) are also available on the Census Bureau website at http://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/demo/international-programs/subnationalpopulation.html for download.
